trans-unit.source: How to work with the Node.js backend server SDK for Mobile Apps | Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: How to work with the Node.js backend server SDK for Mobile Apps | Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Learn how to work with the Node.js backend server SDK for Azure App Service Mobile Apps.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to work with the Node.js backend server SDK for Azure App Service Mobile Apps.

trans-unit.source: How to use the Azure Mobile Apps Node.js SDK
trans-unit.target: How to use the Azure Mobile Apps Node.js SDK

trans-unit.source: This article provides detailed information and examples showing how to work with a Node.js backend in Azure App Service Mobile Apps.
trans-unit.target: This article provides detailed information and examples showing how to work with a Node.js backend in Azure App Service Mobile Apps.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This SDK is in PREVIEW.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This SDK is in PREVIEW.

trans-unit.source: As a result, we do not recommend that you use this SDK in production.
trans-unit.target: As a result, we do not recommend that you use this SDK in production.

trans-unit.source: The examples in this document use v2.0.0-beta1 of [azure-mobile-apps].
trans-unit.target: The examples in this document use v2.0.0-beta1 of [azure-mobile-apps].

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service Mobile Apps provides the capability to add a mobile-optimized data access Web API to a web application.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service Mobile Apps provides the capability to add a mobile-optimized data access Web API to a web application.

trans-unit.source: The Azure App
trans-unit.target: The Azure App

trans-unit.source: Service Mobile Apps SDK is provided for ASP.NET and Node.js web applications.
trans-unit.target: Service Mobile Apps SDK is provided for ASP.NET and Node.js web applications.

trans-unit.source: The SDK provides the following operations:
trans-unit.target: The SDK provides the following operations:

trans-unit.source: Table operations (Read, Insert, Update, Delete) for data access
trans-unit.target: Table operations (Read, Insert, Update, Delete) for data access

trans-unit.source: Custom API operations
trans-unit.target: Custom API operations

trans-unit.source: Both operations provide for authentication across all identity providers allowed by Azure App Service, including social identity
trans-unit.target: Both operations provide for authentication across all identity providers allowed by Azure App Service, including social identity

trans-unit.source: providers such as Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft as well as Azure Active Directory for enterprise identity.
trans-unit.target: providers such as Facebook, Twitter, Google and Microsoft as well as Azure Active Directory for enterprise identity.

trans-unit.source: You can find samples for each use case in the [samples directory on GitHub].
trans-unit.target: You can find samples for each use case in the [samples directory on GitHub].

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a Basic Node.js backend using the Command Line
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a Basic Node.js backend using the Command Line

trans-unit.source: Every Azure App Service Mobile App Node.js backend starts as an ExpressJS application.
trans-unit.target: Every Azure App Service Mobile App Node.js backend starts as an ExpressJS application.

trans-unit.source: ExpressJS is the most popular web service framework
trans-unit.target: ExpressJS is the most popular web service framework

trans-unit.source: available for Node.js.
trans-unit.target: available for Node.js.

trans-unit.source: You can create a basic [Express] application as follows:
trans-unit.target: You can create a basic [Express] application as follows:

trans-unit.source: In a command or PowerShell window, create a new directory for your project.
trans-unit.target: In a command or PowerShell window, create a new directory for your project.

trans-unit.source: Run npm init to initialize the package structure.
trans-unit.target: Run npm init to initialize the package structure.

trans-unit.source: The npm init command will ask a set of questions to initialize the project.
trans-unit.target: The npm init command will ask a set of questions to initialize the project.

trans-unit.source: See the example output below
trans-unit.target: See the example output below

trans-unit.source: The npm init output
trans-unit.target: The npm init output

trans-unit.source: Install the express and azure-mobile-apps libraries from the npm repository.
trans-unit.target: Install the express and azure-mobile-apps libraries from the npm repository.

trans-unit.source: Create an app.js file to implement the basic mobile server.
trans-unit.target: Create an app.js file to implement the basic mobile server.

trans-unit.source: This application creates a simple mobile-optimized WebAPI with a single endpoint (`/tables/TodoItem`) that provides
trans-unit.target: This application creates a simple mobile-optimized WebAPI with a single endpoint (`/tables/TodoItem`) that provides

trans-unit.source: unauthenticated access to an underlying SQL data store using a dynamic schema.
trans-unit.target: unauthenticated access to an underlying SQL data store using a dynamic schema.

trans-unit.source: It is suitable for following the
trans-unit.target: It is suitable for following the

trans-unit.source: client library quick starts:
trans-unit.target: client library quick starts:

trans-unit.source: Android Client QuickStart
trans-unit.target: Android Client QuickStart

trans-unit.source: iOS Client QuickStart
trans-unit.target: iOS Client QuickStart

trans-unit.source: Windows Store Client QuickStart
trans-unit.target: Windows Store Client QuickStart

trans-unit.source: Xamarin.iOS Client QuickStart
trans-unit.target: Xamarin.iOS Client QuickStart

trans-unit.source: Xamarin.Android Client QuickStart
trans-unit.target: Xamarin.Android Client QuickStart

trans-unit.source: Xamarin.Forms Client QuickStart
trans-unit.target: Xamarin.Forms Client QuickStart

trans-unit.source: You can find the code for this basic application in the [basicapp sample on GitHub].
trans-unit.target: You can find the code for this basic application in the [basicapp sample on GitHub].

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a Node backend with Visual Studio 2015
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a Node backend with Visual Studio 2015

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015 requires an extension to develop Node.js applications within the IDE.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015 requires an extension to develop Node.js applications within the IDE.

trans-unit.source: To start, download and install the [Node.js Tools 1.1 for Visual Studio].
trans-unit.target: To start, download and install the [Node.js Tools 1.1 for Visual Studio].

trans-unit.source: Once the Node.js Tools for Visual Studio are installed, create an Express 4.x application:
trans-unit.target: Once the Node.js Tools for Visual Studio are installed, create an Express 4.x application:

trans-unit.source: Open the **New Project** dialog (from **File** > **New** > **Project...**).
trans-unit.target: Open the **New Project** dialog (from **File** > **New** > **Project...**).

trans-unit.source: Expand **Templates** > **JavaScript** > **Node.js**.
trans-unit.target: Expand **Templates** > **JavaScript** > **Node.js**.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Basic Azure Node.js Express 4 Application**.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Basic Azure Node.js Express 4 Application**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the project name.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the project name.

trans-unit.source: Click on *OK*.
trans-unit.target: Click on *OK*.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2015 New Project
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2015 New Project

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the **npm** node and select **Install New npm packages...**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the **npm** node and select **Install New npm packages...**.

trans-unit.source: You may need to refresh the npm catalog on creating your first Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: You may need to refresh the npm catalog on creating your first Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: If this is required, you will be prompted - click on **Refresh**.
trans-unit.target: If this is required, you will be prompted - click on **Refresh**.

trans-unit.source: Enter _azure-mobile-apps_ in the search box.
trans-unit.target: Enter _azure-mobile-apps_ in the search box.

trans-unit.source: Click on the **azure-mobile-apps 2.0.0** package, then click on **Install Package**.
trans-unit.target: Click on the **azure-mobile-apps 2.0.0** package, then click on **Install Package**.

trans-unit.source: Install New npm packages
trans-unit.target: Install New npm packages

trans-unit.source: Click on **Close**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **Close**.

trans-unit.source: Open the _app.js_ file to add support for the Azure Mobile Apps SDK.
trans-unit.target: Open the _app.js_ file to add support for the Azure Mobile Apps SDK.

trans-unit.source: At line 6 at the bottom of the library require statements, add the following code:
trans-unit.target: At line 6 at the bottom of the library require statements, add the following code:

trans-unit.source: At approximately line 27 after the other app.use statements, add the following code:
trans-unit.target: At approximately line 27 after the other app.use statements, add the following code:

trans-unit.source: Save the file.
trans-unit.target: Save the file.

trans-unit.source: Either run the application locally (the API will be served on http://localhost:3000) or publish to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Either run the application locally (the API will be served on http://localhost:3000) or publish to Azure.

trans-unit.source: How to: Download the Node.js backend quickstart code project using Git
trans-unit.target: How to: Download the Node.js backend quickstart code project using Git

trans-unit.source: When you create a new Node.js Mobile App backend by using the portal **Quick start** blade, a new Node.js project is created for you and deployed to your site.
trans-unit.target: When you create a new Node.js Mobile App backend by using the portal **Quick start** blade, a new Node.js project is created for you and deployed to your site.

trans-unit.source: You can add tables and APIs and edit code files for the Node.js backend in the portal.
trans-unit.target: You can add tables and APIs and edit code files for the Node.js backend in the portal.

trans-unit.source: You can also use one of a variety of deployment tools to download the backend project so that you can add or modify tables and APIs, then republish the project.
trans-unit.target: You can also use one of a variety of deployment tools to download the backend project so that you can add or modify tables and APIs, then republish the project.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Azure App Service Deployment Guide].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Azure App Service Deployment Guide].

trans-unit.source: the following procedure uses a Git repository to download the quickstart project code.
trans-unit.target: the following procedure uses a Git repository to download the quickstart project code.

trans-unit.source: Install Git, if you haven't already done so.
trans-unit.target: Install Git, if you haven't already done so.

trans-unit.source: The steps required to install Git vary between operating systems.
trans-unit.target: The steps required to install Git vary between operating systems.

trans-unit.source: See [Installing Git](http://git-scm.com/book/en/Getting-Started-Installing-Git) for operating system specific distributions and installation guidance.
trans-unit.target: See [Installing Git](http://git-scm.com/book/en/Getting-Started-Installing-Git) for operating system specific distributions and installation guidance.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in [Enable the web app repository](../app-service-web/web-sites-publish-source-control.md#Step4) to enable the Git repository for your backend site, making a note of the deployment username and password.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in [Enable the web app repository](../app-service-web/web-sites-publish-source-control.md#Step4) to enable the Git repository for your backend site, making a note of the deployment username and password.

trans-unit.source: In the blade for your Mobile App backend, make a note of the **Git clone URL** setting.
trans-unit.target: In the blade for your Mobile App backend, make a note of the **Git clone URL** setting.

trans-unit.source: Execute the `git clone` command in a Git-aware command-line tool using the Git clone URL, entering your password when required, as in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Execute the `git clone` command in a Git-aware command-line tool using the Git clone URL, entering your password when required, as in the following example:

trans-unit.source: Browse to local directory, which in the above example is /todolist, and notice that project files have been downloaded.
trans-unit.target: Browse to local directory, which in the above example is /todolist, and notice that project files have been downloaded.

trans-unit.source: In the /tables subfolder you will find a todoitem.json file, which defines permissions on the table, and todoitem.js file, which defines that CRUD operation scripts for the table.
trans-unit.target: In the /tables subfolder you will find a todoitem.json file, which defines permissions on the table, and todoitem.js file, which defines that CRUD operation scripts for the table.

trans-unit.source: After you have made changes to project files, execute the following commands to add, commit, then upload the changes to the site:
trans-unit.target: After you have made changes to project files, execute the following commands to add, commit, then upload the changes to the site:

trans-unit.source: When you add new files to the project, you first need to execute the `git add .` command.
trans-unit.target: When you add new files to the project, you first need to execute the `git add .` command.

trans-unit.source: The site is republished every time a new set of commits is pushed to the site.
trans-unit.target: The site is republished every time a new set of commits is pushed to the site.

trans-unit.source: How to: Publish your Node.js backend to Azure
trans-unit.target: How to: Publish your Node.js backend to Azure

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure provides many mechanisms for publishing your Azure App Service Mobile Apps Node.js backend to the Azure service.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure provides many mechanisms for publishing your Azure App Service Mobile Apps Node.js backend to the Azure service.

trans-unit.source: These include utilizing deployment tools integrated into Visual Studio, command-line tools and continuous deployment options based on source control.
trans-unit.target: These include utilizing deployment tools integrated into Visual Studio, command-line tools and continuous deployment options based on source control.

trans-unit.source: For more information on this topic, refer to the [Azure App Service Deployment Guide].
trans-unit.target: For more information on this topic, refer to the [Azure App Service Deployment Guide].

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service has specific advice for Node.js application that you should review before deploying:
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service has specific advice for Node.js application that you should review before deploying:

trans-unit.source: How to [specify the Node Version]
trans-unit.target: How to [specify the Node Version]

trans-unit.source: How to [use Node modules]
trans-unit.target: How to [use Node modules]

trans-unit.source: Table operations
trans-unit.target: Table operations

trans-unit.source: The azure-mobile-apps Node.js Server SDK provides mechanisms to expose data tables stored in Azure SQL Database as a WebAPI.
trans-unit.target: The azure-mobile-apps Node.js Server SDK provides mechanisms to expose data tables stored in Azure SQL Database as a WebAPI.

trans-unit.source: Five operations are provided.
trans-unit.target: Five operations are provided.

trans-unit.source: Operation
trans-unit.target: Operation

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: GET /tables/_tablename_
trans-unit.target: GET /tables/_tablename_

trans-unit.source: Get all records in the table
trans-unit.target: Get all records in the table

trans-unit.source: GET /tables/_tablename_/:id
trans-unit.target: GET /tables/_tablename_/:id

trans-unit.source: Get a specific record in the table
trans-unit.target: Get a specific record in the table

trans-unit.source: POST /tables/_tablename_
trans-unit.target: POST /tables/_tablename_

trans-unit.source: Create a new record in the table
trans-unit.target: Create a new record in the table

trans-unit.source: PATCH /tables/_tablename_/:id
trans-unit.target: PATCH /tables/_tablename_/:id

trans-unit.source: Update an existing record in the table
trans-unit.target: Update an existing record in the table

trans-unit.source: DELETE /tables/_tablename_/:id
trans-unit.target: DELETE /tables/_tablename_/:id

trans-unit.source: Delete a record in the table
trans-unit.target: Delete a record in the table

trans-unit.source: This WebAPI supports [OData] and extends the table schema to support [offline data sync].
trans-unit.target: This WebAPI supports [OData] and extends the table schema to support [offline data sync].

trans-unit.source: How to: Define tables using a dynamic schema
trans-unit.target: How to: Define tables using a dynamic schema

trans-unit.source: Before a table can be used, it must be defined.
trans-unit.target: Before a table can be used, it must be defined.

trans-unit.source: Tables can be defined with a static schema (where the developer defines the columns within the schema) or dynamically (where the SDK controls the schema based on incoming requests).
trans-unit.target: Tables can be defined with a static schema (where the developer defines the columns within the schema) or dynamically (where the SDK controls the schema based on incoming requests).

trans-unit.source: In addition, the developer can control specific aspects of the WebAPI by adding Javascript code to the definition.
trans-unit.target: In addition, the developer can control specific aspects of the WebAPI by adding Javascript code to the definition.

trans-unit.source: As a best practice, you should define each table in a Javascript file in the tables directory, then use the tables.import() method to import the tables.
trans-unit.target: As a best practice, you should define each table in a Javascript file in the tables directory, then use the tables.import() method to import the tables.

trans-unit.source: Extending the basic-app, the app.js file would be adjusted:
trans-unit.target: Extending the basic-app, the app.js file would be adjusted:

trans-unit.source: Define the table in ./tables/TodoItem.js:
trans-unit.target: Define the table in ./tables/TodoItem.js:

trans-unit.source: Tables use dynamic schema by default.
trans-unit.target: Tables use dynamic schema by default.

trans-unit.source: To turn off dynamic schema globally, set the App Setting **MS_DynamicSchema** to false within the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: To turn off dynamic schema globally, set the App Setting **MS_DynamicSchema** to false within the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: You can find a complete example in the [todo sample on GitHub].
trans-unit.target: You can find a complete example in the [todo sample on GitHub].

trans-unit.source: How to: Define tables using a static schema
trans-unit.target: How to: Define tables using a static schema

trans-unit.source: You can explicitly define the columns to expose via the WebAPI.
trans-unit.target: You can explicitly define the columns to expose via the WebAPI.

trans-unit.source: The azure-mobile-apps Node.js SDK will automatically add any additional columns required for offline data sync to the list that you provide.
trans-unit.target: The azure-mobile-apps Node.js SDK will automatically add any additional columns required for offline data sync to the list that you provide.

trans-unit.source: For example, the QuickStart client applications require a table with two columns: text (a string) and complete (a boolean).
trans-unit.target: For example, the QuickStart client applications require a table with two columns: text (a string) and complete (a boolean).

trans-unit.source: This can be defined in the table definition JavaScript file (located in the tables directory) as follows:
trans-unit.target: This can be defined in the table definition JavaScript file (located in the tables directory) as follows:

trans-unit.source: If you define tables statically, then you must also call the tables.initialize() method to create the database schema on startup.
trans-unit.target: If you define tables statically, then you must also call the tables.initialize() method to create the database schema on startup.

trans-unit.source: The tables.initialize() method returns a [Promise] - this is used to ensure that the web service does not serve requests prior to the database being initialized.
trans-unit.target: The tables.initialize() method returns a [Promise] - this is used to ensure that the web service does not serve requests prior to the database being initialized.

trans-unit.source: How to: Use SQL Express as a development data store on your local machine
trans-unit.target: How to: Use SQL Express as a development data store on your local machine

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile Apps The AzureMobile Apps Node SDK provides three options for serving data out of the box: SDK provides three options for serving data out of the box:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile Apps The AzureMobile Apps Node SDK provides three options for serving data out of the box: SDK provides three options for serving data out of the box:

trans-unit.source: Use the **memory** driver to provide a non-persistent example store
trans-unit.target: Use the **memory** driver to provide a non-persistent example store

trans-unit.source: Use the **mssql** driver to provide a SQL Express data store for development
trans-unit.target: Use the **mssql** driver to provide a SQL Express data store for development

trans-unit.source: Use the **mssql** driver to provide an Azure SQL Database data store for production
trans-unit.target: Use the **mssql** driver to provide an Azure SQL Database data store for production

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile Apps Node.js SDK uses the [mssql Node.js package] to establish and use a connection to both SQL Express and SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile Apps Node.js SDK uses the [mssql Node.js package] to establish and use a connection to both SQL Express and SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: This package requires that you enable TCP connections on your SQL Express instance.
trans-unit.target: This package requires that you enable TCP connections on your SQL Express instance.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] The memory driver does not provide a complete set of facilities for testing.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] The memory driver does not provide a complete set of facilities for testing.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to test your backend locally,
trans-unit.target: If you wish to test your backend locally,

trans-unit.source: we recommend the use of a SQL Express data store and the mssql driver.
trans-unit.target: we recommend the use of a SQL Express data store and the mssql driver.

trans-unit.source: Download and install [Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Express].
trans-unit.target: Download and install [Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Express].

trans-unit.source: Ensure you install the SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools edition.
trans-unit.target: Ensure you install the SQL Server 2014 Express with Tools edition.

trans-unit.source: Unless you explicitly
trans-unit.target: Unless you explicitly

trans-unit.source: require 64 Bit support, the 32 Bit version will consume less memory when running.
trans-unit.target: require 64 Bit support, the 32 Bit version will consume less memory when running.

trans-unit.source: Run the SQL Server 2014 Configuration Manager.
trans-unit.target: Run the SQL Server 2014 Configuration Manager.

trans-unit.source: Expand the **SQL Server Network Configuration** node in the left hand tree menu.
trans-unit.target: Expand the **SQL Server Network Configuration** node in the left hand tree menu.

trans-unit.source: Click on **Protocols for SQLEXPRESS**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **Protocols for SQLEXPRESS**.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on **TCP/IP** and select **Enable**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on **TCP/IP** and select **Enable**.

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK** in the pop-up dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK** in the pop-up dialog.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on **TCP/IP** and select **Properties**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on **TCP/IP** and select **Properties**.

trans-unit.source: Click on the **IP Addresses** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click on the **IP Addresses** tab.

trans-unit.source: Find the **IPAll** node.
trans-unit.target: Find the **IPAll** node.

trans-unit.source: In the **TCP Port** field, enter **1433**.
trans-unit.target: In the **TCP Port** field, enter **1433**.

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK** in the pop-up dialog.
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK** in the pop-up dialog.

trans-unit.source: Click on **SQL Server Services** in the left hand tree menu.
trans-unit.target: Click on **SQL Server Services** in the left hand tree menu.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on **SQL Server (SQLEXPRESS)** and select **Restart**
trans-unit.target: Right-click on **SQL Server (SQLEXPRESS)** and select **Restart**

trans-unit.source: Close the SQL Server 2014 Configuration Manager.
trans-unit.target: Close the SQL Server 2014 Configuration Manager.

trans-unit.source: Run the SQL Server 2014 Management Studio and connect to your local SQL Express instance
trans-unit.target: Run the SQL Server 2014 Management Studio and connect to your local SQL Express instance

trans-unit.source: Right-click on your instance in the Object Explorer and select **Properties**
trans-unit.target: Right-click on your instance in the Object Explorer and select **Properties**

trans-unit.source: Select the **Security** page.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Security** page.

trans-unit.source: Ensure the **SQL Server and Windows Authentication mode** is selected
trans-unit.target: Ensure the **SQL Server and Windows Authentication mode** is selected

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK**
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK**

trans-unit.source: Configure SQL Express Authentication
trans-unit.target: Configure SQL Express Authentication

trans-unit.source: Expand **Security** > **Logins** in the Object Explorer
trans-unit.target: Expand **Security** > **Logins** in the Object Explorer

trans-unit.source: Right-click on **Logins** and select **New Login...**
trans-unit.target: Right-click on **Logins** and select **New Login...**

trans-unit.source: Enter a Login name.
trans-unit.target: Enter a Login name.

trans-unit.source: Select **SQL Server authentication**.
trans-unit.target: Select **SQL Server authentication**.

trans-unit.source: Enter a Password, then enter the same password in **Confirm password**.
trans-unit.target: Enter a Password, then enter the same password in **Confirm password**.

trans-unit.source: Note that the password must meet Windows complexity requirement.
trans-unit.target: Note that the password must meet Windows complexity requirement.

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK**
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK**

trans-unit.source: Add a new user to SQL Express
trans-unit.target: Add a new user to SQL Express

trans-unit.source: Right-click on your new login and select **Properties**
trans-unit.target: Right-click on your new login and select **Properties**

trans-unit.source: Select the **Server Roles** page
trans-unit.target: Select the **Server Roles** page

trans-unit.source: Check the box next to the **dbcreator** server role
trans-unit.target: Check the box next to the **dbcreator** server role

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK**
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK**

trans-unit.source: Close the SQL Server 2015 Management Studio
trans-unit.target: Close the SQL Server 2015 Management Studio

trans-unit.source: Ensure you record the username and password you selected.
trans-unit.target: Ensure you record the username and password you selected.

trans-unit.source: You may need to assign additional server roles or permissions depending on your specific database requirements.
trans-unit.target: You may need to assign additional server roles or permissions depending on your specific database requirements.

trans-unit.source: The Node.js application will read the **SQLCONNSTR_MS_TableConnectionString** environment variable to read the connection string for this database.
trans-unit.target: The Node.js application will read the **SQLCONNSTR_MS_TableConnectionString** environment variable to read the connection string for this database.

trans-unit.source: You can set this within your environment.
trans-unit.target: You can set this within your environment.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use PowerShell to set this environment variable:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use PowerShell to set this environment variable:

trans-unit.source: Note that you must access the database through a TCP/IP connection and provide a username and password for the connection.
trans-unit.target: Note that you must access the database through a TCP/IP connection and provide a username and password for the connection.

trans-unit.source: How to: Configure your project for local development
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure your project for local development

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Apps reads a JavaScript file called _azureMobile.js_ from the local filesystem.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Apps reads a JavaScript file called _azureMobile.js_ from the local filesystem.

trans-unit.source: You should not use this file to configure the Azure Mobile Apps SDK in production - use App Settings within the [Azure Portal] instead.
trans-unit.target: You should not use this file to configure the Azure Mobile Apps SDK in production - use App Settings within the [Azure Portal] instead.

trans-unit.source: The _azureMobile.js_ file should export a configuration object.
trans-unit.target: The _azureMobile.js_ file should export a configuration object.

trans-unit.source: The most common settings are:
trans-unit.target: The most common settings are:

trans-unit.source: Database Settings
trans-unit.target: Database Settings

trans-unit.source: Diagnostic Logging Settings
trans-unit.target: Diagnostic Logging Settings

trans-unit.source: Alternate CORS Settings
trans-unit.target: Alternate CORS Settings

trans-unit.source: An example _azureMobile.js_ file implementing the database settings given above is below:
trans-unit.target: An example _azureMobile.js_ file implementing the database settings given above is below:

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you add _azureMobile.js_ to your _.gitignore_ file (or other source code control ignore file) to prevent passwords from
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you add _azureMobile.js_ to your _.gitignore_ file (or other source code control ignore file) to prevent passwords from

trans-unit.source: being stored in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: being stored in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Always configure production settings in App Settings within the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: Always configure production settings in App Settings within the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: <a name="howto-appsettings"><a>App Settings for configuring your Mobile App
trans-unit.target: <a name="howto-appsettings"><a>App Settings for configuring your Mobile App

trans-unit.source: Most settings in the _azureMobile.js_ file have an equivalent App Setting in the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: Most settings in the _azureMobile.js_ file have an equivalent App Setting in the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: Use the following list to configure your
trans-unit.target: Use the following list to configure your

trans-unit.source: app in App Settings:
trans-unit.target: app in App Settings:

trans-unit.source: App Setting
trans-unit.target: App Setting

trans-unit.source: _azureMobile.js_ Setting
trans-unit.target: _azureMobile.js_ Setting

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Valid Values
trans-unit.target: Valid Values

trans-unit.source: MS_MobileAppName
trans-unit.target: MS_MobileAppName

trans-unit.source: name
trans-unit.target: name

trans-unit.source: The name of the app
trans-unit.target: The name of the app

trans-unit.source: string
trans-unit.target: string

trans-unit.source: MS_MobileLoggingLevel
trans-unit.target: MS_MobileLoggingLevel

trans-unit.source: logging.level
trans-unit.target: logging.level

trans-unit.source: Minimum log level of messages to log
trans-unit.target: Minimum log level of messages to log

trans-unit.source: error, warning, info, verbose, debug, silly
trans-unit.target: error, warning, info, verbose, debug, silly

trans-unit.source: MS_DebugMode
trans-unit.target: MS_DebugMode

trans-unit.source: debug
trans-unit.target: debug

trans-unit.source: Enable or Disable debug mode
trans-unit.target: Enable or Disable debug mode

trans-unit.source: true, false
trans-unit.target: true, false

trans-unit.source: MS_TableSchema
trans-unit.target: MS_TableSchema

trans-unit.source: data.schema
trans-unit.target: data.schema

trans-unit.source: Default schema name for SQL tables
trans-unit.target: Default schema name for SQL tables

trans-unit.source: string (default: dbo)
trans-unit.target: string (default: dbo)

trans-unit.source: MS_DynamicSchema
trans-unit.target: MS_DynamicSchema

trans-unit.source: data.dynamicSchema
trans-unit.target: data.dynamicSchema

trans-unit.source: Enable or Disable debug mode
trans-unit.target: Enable or Disable debug mode

trans-unit.source: true, false
trans-unit.target: true, false

trans-unit.source: MS_DisableVersionHeader
trans-unit.target: MS_DisableVersionHeader

trans-unit.source: version (set to undefined)
trans-unit.target: version (set to undefined)

trans-unit.source: Disables the X-ZUMO-Server-Version header
trans-unit.target: Disables the X-ZUMO-Server-Version header

trans-unit.source: true, false
trans-unit.target: true, false

trans-unit.source: MS_SkipVersionCheck
trans-unit.target: MS_SkipVersionCheck

trans-unit.source: skipversioncheck
trans-unit.target: skipversioncheck

trans-unit.source: Disables the client API version check
trans-unit.target: Disables the client API version check

trans-unit.source: true, false
trans-unit.target: true, false

trans-unit.source: To set an App Setting:
trans-unit.target: To set an App Setting:

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: Select **All resources** or **App Services** then click on the name of your Mobile App.
trans-unit.target: Select **All resources** or **App Services** then click on the name of your Mobile App.

trans-unit.source: The Settings blade will open by default - if it doesn't, click on **Settings**.
trans-unit.target: The Settings blade will open by default - if it doesn't, click on **Settings**.

trans-unit.source: Click on **Application settings** in the GENERAL menu.
trans-unit.target: Click on **Application settings** in the GENERAL menu.

trans-unit.source: Scroll to the App Settings section.
trans-unit.target: Scroll to the App Settings section.

trans-unit.source: If your app setting already exists, click on the value of the app setting to edit the value.
trans-unit.target: If your app setting already exists, click on the value of the app setting to edit the value.

trans-unit.source: If you app setting does not exist, enter the App Setting in the Key box and the value in the Value box.
trans-unit.target: If you app setting does not exist, enter the App Setting in the Key box and the value in the Value box.

trans-unit.source: Once you are complete, click on **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Once you are complete, click on **Save**.

trans-unit.source: Changing most app settings will require a service restart.
trans-unit.target: Changing most app settings will require a service restart.

trans-unit.source: How to: Use SQL Database as your production data store
trans-unit.target: How to: Use SQL Database as your production data store

trans-unit.source: Using Azure SQL Database as a data store is identical across all Azure App Service application types.
trans-unit.target: Using Azure SQL Database as a data store is identical across all Azure App Service application types.

trans-unit.source: If you have not done so already, follow these steps to create a new Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: If you have not done so already, follow these steps to create a new Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: Log into the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: Log into the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: In the top left of the window, click the **+NEW** button > **Web + Mobile** > **Mobile App**, then provide a name for your Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: In the top left of the window, click the **+NEW** button > **Web + Mobile** > **Mobile App**, then provide a name for your Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: In the **Resource Group** box, enter the same name as your app.
trans-unit.target: In the **Resource Group** box, enter the same name as your app.

trans-unit.source: The Default App Service plan will be selected.
trans-unit.target: The Default App Service plan will be selected.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to change your App Service plan, you can do so by clicking on the App Service Plan > **+ Create New**.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to change your App Service plan, you can do so by clicking on the App Service Plan > **+ Create New**.

trans-unit.source: Provide a name of the new App Service plan and select an appropriate location.
trans-unit.target: Provide a name of the new App Service plan and select an appropriate location.

trans-unit.source: Click the Pricing tier and select an appropriate pricing tier for the service.
trans-unit.target: Click the Pricing tier and select an appropriate pricing tier for the service.

trans-unit.source: Select **View all** to view more pricing options, such as **Free** and **Shared**.
trans-unit.target: Select **View all** to view more pricing options, such as **Free** and **Shared**.

trans-unit.source: Once you have selected the pricing tier, click the **Select** button.
trans-unit.target: Once you have selected the pricing tier, click the **Select** button.

trans-unit.source: Back in the **App Service plan** blade, click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Back in the **App Service plan** blade, click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: This creates a Mobile App backend where you will later deploy your server project.
trans-unit.target: This creates a Mobile App backend where you will later deploy your server project.

trans-unit.source: Provisioning a Mobile App backend can take a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: Provisioning a Mobile App backend can take a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: Once the Mobile App backend is provisioned, the portal will open the **Settings** blade for the Mobile App backend.
trans-unit.target: Once the Mobile App backend is provisioned, the portal will open the **Settings** blade for the Mobile App backend.

trans-unit.source: Once the Mobile App backend is created, you can choose to either connect an existing SQL database to your Mobile App backend or create a new SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Once the Mobile App backend is created, you can choose to either connect an existing SQL database to your Mobile App backend or create a new SQL database.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we will create a new SQL database.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we will create a new SQL database.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you already have a database in the same location as the new mobile app backend, you can instead choose **Use an existing database** and then select that database.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you already have a database in the same location as the new mobile app backend, you can instead choose **Use an existing database** and then select that database.

trans-unit.source: The use of a database in a different location is not recommended because of additional bandwidth costs and higher latencies.
trans-unit.target: The use of a database in a different location is not recommended because of additional bandwidth costs and higher latencies.

trans-unit.source: In the new Mobile App backend, click **Settings** > **Mobile App** > **Data** > **+Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the new Mobile App backend, click **Settings** > **Mobile App** > **Data** > **+Add**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Add data connection** blade, click **SQL Database - Configure required settings** > **Create a new database**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add data connection** blade, click **SQL Database - Configure required settings** > **Create a new database**.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of the new database in the **Name** field.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of the new database in the **Name** field.

trans-unit.source: Click **Server**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Server**.

trans-unit.source: In the **New server** blade, enter a unique server name in the **Server name** field, and provide a suitable **Server admin login** and **Password**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New server** blade, enter a unique server name in the **Server name** field, and provide a suitable **Server admin login** and **Password**.

trans-unit.source: Ensure **Allow azure services to access server** is checked.
trans-unit.target: Ensure **Allow azure services to access server** is checked.

trans-unit.source: Click on **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Click on **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: On the **New database** blade, click on **OK**.
trans-unit.target: On the **New database** blade, click on **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Back on the **Add data connection** blade, select **Connection string**, enter the login and password that you just provided when creating the database.
trans-unit.target: Back on the **Add data connection** blade, select **Connection string**, enter the login and password that you just provided when creating the database.

trans-unit.source: If you use an existing database, provide the login credentials for that database.
trans-unit.target: If you use an existing database, provide the login credentials for that database.

trans-unit.source: Once entered, click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Once entered, click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Back on the **Add data connection** blade again, click on **OK** to create the database.
trans-unit.target: Back on the **Add data connection** blade again, click on **OK** to create the database.

trans-unit.source: Creation of the database can take a few minutes.
trans-unit.target: Creation of the database can take a few minutes.

trans-unit.source: Use the **Notifications** area to monitor the progress of the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Use the **Notifications** area to monitor the progress of the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Do not progress until the database has been deployed sucessfully.
trans-unit.target: Do not progress until the database has been deployed sucessfully.

trans-unit.source: Once successfully deployed, a Connection String will be created for the SQL Database instance in your Mobile backend App Settings.
trans-unit.target: Once successfully deployed, a Connection String will be created for the SQL Database instance in your Mobile backend App Settings.

trans-unit.source: You can see this app setting in the **Settings** > **Application settings** > **Connection strings**.
trans-unit.target: You can see this app setting in the **Settings** > **Application settings** > **Connection strings**.

trans-unit.source: How to: Require Authentication for access to tables
trans-unit.target: How to: Require Authentication for access to tables

trans-unit.source: If you wish to use App Service Authentication with the tables endpoint, you must configure App Service Authentication in the [Azure Portal] first.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to use App Service Authentication with the tables endpoint, you must configure App Service Authentication in the [Azure Portal] first.

trans-unit.source: For
trans-unit.target: For

trans-unit.source: more details about configuring authentication in an Azure App Service, review the Configuration Guide for the identity provider you intend to use:
trans-unit.target: more details about configuring authentication in an Azure App Service, review the Configuration Guide for the identity provider you intend to use:

trans-unit.source: How to configure Azure Active Directory Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Azure Active Directory Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Facebook Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Facebook Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Google Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Google Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Microsoft Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Microsoft Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Twitter Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Twitter Authentication

trans-unit.source: Each table has an access property that can be used to control access to the table.
trans-unit.target: Each table has an access property that can be used to control access to the table.

trans-unit.source: The following sample shows a statically defined table with authentication required.
trans-unit.target: The following sample shows a statically defined table with authentication required.

trans-unit.source: The access property can take one of three values
trans-unit.target: The access property can take one of three values

trans-unit.source: *anonymous* indicates that the client application is allowed to read data without authentication
trans-unit.target: *anonymous* indicates that the client application is allowed to read data without authentication

trans-unit.source: *authenticated* indicates that the client application must send a valid authentication token with the request
trans-unit.target: *authenticated* indicates that the client application must send a valid authentication token with the request

trans-unit.source: *disabled* indicates that this table is currently disabled
trans-unit.target: *disabled* indicates that this table is currently disabled

trans-unit.source: If the access property is undefined, unauthenticated access is allowed.
trans-unit.target: If the access property is undefined, unauthenticated access is allowed.

trans-unit.source: How to: Disable access to specific table operations
trans-unit.target: How to: Disable access to specific table operations

trans-unit.source: In addition to appearing on the table, the access property can be used to control individual operations.
trans-unit.target: In addition to appearing on the table, the access property can be used to control individual operations.

trans-unit.source: There are four operations:
trans-unit.target: There are four operations:

trans-unit.source: *read* is the RESTful GET operation on the table
trans-unit.target: *read* is the RESTful GET operation on the table

trans-unit.source: *insert* is the RESTful POST operation on the table
trans-unit.target: *insert* is the RESTful POST operation on the table

trans-unit.source: *update* is the RESTful PATCH operation on the table
trans-unit.target: *update* is the RESTful PATCH operation on the table

trans-unit.source: *delete* is the RESTful DELETE operation on the table
trans-unit.target: *delete* is the RESTful DELETE operation on the table

trans-unit.source: For example, you may wish to provide a read-only unauthenticated table.
trans-unit.target: For example, you may wish to provide a read-only unauthenticated table.

trans-unit.source: This can be provided by the following table definition:
trans-unit.target: This can be provided by the following table definition:

trans-unit.source: How to: Adjust the query that is used with table operations
trans-unit.target: How to: Adjust the query that is used with table operations

trans-unit.source: A common requirement for table operations is to provide a restricted view of the data.
trans-unit.target: A common requirement for table operations is to provide a restricted view of the data.

trans-unit.source: For example, you may provide a table that is
trans-unit.target: For example, you may provide a table that is

trans-unit.source: tagged with the authenticated user ID such that the user can only read or update their own records.
trans-unit.target: tagged with the authenticated user ID such that the user can only read or update their own records.

trans-unit.source: The following table definition
trans-unit.target: The following table definition

trans-unit.source: will provide this functionality:
trans-unit.target: will provide this functionality:

trans-unit.source: Operations that normally execute a query will have a query property that you can adjust with a where clause.
trans-unit.target: Operations that normally execute a query will have a query property that you can adjust with a where clause.

trans-unit.source: The query property is
trans-unit.target: The query property is

trans-unit.source: a [QueryJS] object that is used to convert an OData query to something that the data backend can process.
trans-unit.target: a [QueryJS] object that is used to convert an OData query to something that the data backend can process.

trans-unit.source: For simple equality cases
trans-unit.target: For simple equality cases

trans-unit.source: (like the one above), a map can be used.
trans-unit.target: (like the one above), a map can be used.

trans-unit.source: It is also relatively easy to add specific SQL clauses:
trans-unit.target: It is also relatively easy to add specific SQL clauses:

trans-unit.source: How to: Configure Soft Delete on a table
trans-unit.target: How to: Configure Soft Delete on a table

trans-unit.source: Soft Delete does not actually delete records.
trans-unit.target: Soft Delete does not actually delete records.

trans-unit.source: Instead it marks them as deleted within the database by setting the deleted column to true.
trans-unit.target: Instead it marks them as deleted within the database by setting the deleted column to true.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Mobile Apps SDK automatically removes soft-deleted records from results unless the Mobile Client SDK uses IncludeDeleted().
trans-unit.target: The Azure Mobile Apps SDK automatically removes soft-deleted records from results unless the Mobile Client SDK uses IncludeDeleted().

trans-unit.source: To configure a table for soft delete, set the softDelete property in the table definition file.
trans-unit.target: To configure a table for soft delete, set the softDelete property in the table definition file.

trans-unit.source: An example might be:
trans-unit.target: An example might be:

trans-unit.source: You will need to establish a mechanism for purging records - either from a client application, via a WebJob or through a custom mechanism.
trans-unit.target: You will need to establish a mechanism for purging records - either from a client application, via a WebJob or through a custom mechanism.

trans-unit.source: How to: Seed your database with data
trans-unit.target: How to: Seed your database with data

trans-unit.source: When creating a new application, you may wish to seed a table with data.
trans-unit.target: When creating a new application, you may wish to seed a table with data.

trans-unit.source: This can be done within the table definition JavaScript file as
trans-unit.target: This can be done within the table definition JavaScript file as

trans-unit.source: follows:
trans-unit.target: follows:

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that seeding of data is only done when the table is created by the Azure Mobile Apps SDK.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that seeding of data is only done when the table is created by the Azure Mobile Apps SDK.

trans-unit.source: If the table already
trans-unit.target: If the table already

trans-unit.source: exists within the database, no data is injected into the table.
trans-unit.target: exists within the database, no data is injected into the table.

trans-unit.source: If dynamic schema is turned on, then the schema will be inferred from
trans-unit.target: If dynamic schema is turned on, then the schema will be inferred from

trans-unit.source: the seeded data.
trans-unit.target: the seeded data.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you explicitly call the initialize() method to create the table when the service starts running.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you explicitly call the initialize() method to create the table when the service starts running.

trans-unit.source: Custom APIs
trans-unit.target: Custom APIs

trans-unit.source: In addition to the data access API via the /tables endpoint, Azure Mobile Apps can provide custom API coverage.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the data access API via the /tables endpoint, Azure Mobile Apps can provide custom API coverage.

trans-unit.source: Custom APIs are defined in
trans-unit.target: Custom APIs are defined in

trans-unit.source: a similar way to the table definitions and can access all the same facilities, including authentication.
trans-unit.target: a similar way to the table definitions and can access all the same facilities, including authentication.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to use App Service Authentication with a Custom API, you must configure App Service Authentication in the [Azure Portal] first.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to use App Service Authentication with a Custom API, you must configure App Service Authentication in the [Azure Portal] first.

trans-unit.source: For
trans-unit.target: For

trans-unit.source: more details about configuring authentication in an Azure App Service, review the Configuration Guide for the identity provider you intend to use:
trans-unit.target: more details about configuring authentication in an Azure App Service, review the Configuration Guide for the identity provider you intend to use:

trans-unit.source: How to configure Azure Active Directory Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Azure Active Directory Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Facebook Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Facebook Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Google Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Google Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Microsoft Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Microsoft Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to configure Twitter Authentication
trans-unit.target: How to configure Twitter Authentication

trans-unit.source: How to: Define a simple custom API
trans-unit.target: How to: Define a simple custom API

trans-unit.source: Custom APIs are defined in much the same way as the Tables API.
trans-unit.target: Custom APIs are defined in much the same way as the Tables API.

trans-unit.source: Create an **api** directory
trans-unit.target: Create an **api** directory

trans-unit.source: Create an API definition JavaScript file in the **api** directory.
trans-unit.target: Create an API definition JavaScript file in the **api** directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the import method to import the **api** directory.
trans-unit.target: Use the import method to import the **api** directory.

trans-unit.source: Here is the prototype api definition based on the basic-app sample we used earlier.
trans-unit.target: Here is the prototype api definition based on the basic-app sample we used earlier.

trans-unit.source: Let's take a simple API that will return the server date using the _Date.now()_ method.
trans-unit.target: Let's take a simple API that will return the server date using the _Date.now()_ method.

trans-unit.source: Here is the api/date.js file:
trans-unit.target: Here is the api/date.js file:

trans-unit.source: Each parameter is one of the standard RESTful verbs - GET, POST, PATCH or DELETE.
trans-unit.target: Each parameter is one of the standard RESTful verbs - GET, POST, PATCH or DELETE.

trans-unit.source: The method is a standard [ExpressJS Middleware] function that sends the required output.
trans-unit.target: The method is a standard [ExpressJS Middleware] function that sends the required output.

trans-unit.source: How to: Require authentication for access to a custom API
trans-unit.target: How to: Require authentication for access to a custom API

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Apps SDK implements authentication in the same way for both the tables endpoint and custom APIs.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Apps SDK implements authentication in the same way for both the tables endpoint and custom APIs.

trans-unit.source: To add authentication to the API developed in the previous section, add an **access** property:
trans-unit.target: To add authentication to the API developed in the previous section, add an **access** property:

trans-unit.source: You can also specify authentication on specific operations:
trans-unit.target: You can also specify authentication on specific operations:

trans-unit.source: The same token that is used for the tables endpoint must be used for custom APIs requiring authentication.
trans-unit.target: The same token that is used for the tables endpoint must be used for custom APIs requiring authentication.

trans-unit.source: Debugging and troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Debugging and troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: The Azure App Service provides several debugging and troubleshooting techniques for Node.js applications.
trans-unit.target: The Azure App Service provides several debugging and troubleshooting techniques for Node.js applications.

trans-unit.source: All of these techniques are available.
trans-unit.target: All of these techniques are available.

trans-unit.source: Monitoring an Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Monitoring an Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Enable Diagnostic Logging in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Enable Diagnostic Logging in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: Toubleshoot an Azure App Service in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Toubleshoot an Azure App Service in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: How to: Write to the Azure Mobile Apps diagnostic logs
trans-unit.target: How to: Write to the Azure Mobile Apps diagnostic logs

trans-unit.source: Node.js applications have access to a wide range of diagnostic log tools.
trans-unit.target: Node.js applications have access to a wide range of diagnostic log tools.

trans-unit.source: Internally, the Azure Mobile Apps Node.js SDK uses [Winston] for diagnostic logging.
trans-unit.target: Internally, the Azure Mobile Apps Node.js SDK uses [Winston] for diagnostic logging.

trans-unit.source: This is automatically enabled by enabling debug mode or by setting the **MS_DebugMode** app setting to true in the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: This is automatically enabled by enabling debug mode or by setting the **MS_DebugMode** app setting to true in the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: Logs generated will appear in the Diagnostic Logs on the [Azure Portal].
trans-unit.target: Logs generated will appear in the Diagnostic Logs on the [Azure Portal].

trans-unit.source: In-portal code editing experience
trans-unit.target: In-portal code editing experience

trans-unit.source: Special tooling in the Azure portal makes it easy to work with a Node.js backend project without having to download the code project.
trans-unit.target: Special tooling in the Azure portal makes it easy to work with a Node.js backend project without having to download the code project.

trans-unit.source: Easy Tables and Easy APIs in the portal let you create and work with tables and custom APIs right in the portal.
trans-unit.target: Easy Tables and Easy APIs in the portal let you create and work with tables and custom APIs right in the portal.

trans-unit.source: You can even edit table operation and API scripts right in the portal using the Visual Studio Team Services "Monaco" editor.
trans-unit.target: You can even edit table operation and API scripts right in the portal using the Visual Studio Team Services "Monaco" editor.

trans-unit.source: How to: Work with Easy Tables in the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: How to: Work with Easy Tables in the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: When you click **Easy tables** in your backend site settings, you can add a new table or modify or delete an existing table.
trans-unit.target: When you click **Easy tables** in your backend site settings, you can add a new table or modify or delete an existing table.

trans-unit.source: You can also see data in the table.
trans-unit.target: You can also see data in the table.

trans-unit.source: Work with Easy Tables
trans-unit.target: Work with Easy Tables

trans-unit.source: The following commands are available on the command bar for a table:
trans-unit.target: The following commands are available on the command bar for a table:

trans-unit.source: **Change permissions** - modify the the permission for read, insert, update and delete operations on the table.
trans-unit.target: **Change permissions** - modify the the permission for read, insert, update and delete operations on the table.

trans-unit.source: Options are to allow anonymous access, to require authentication, or to disable all access to the operation.
trans-unit.target: Options are to allow anonymous access, to require authentication, or to disable all access to the operation.

trans-unit.source: This modifies the table.json project code file.
trans-unit.target: This modifies the table.json project code file.

trans-unit.source: **Edit script** - the script file for the table is opened in the Visual Studio Team Services editor.
trans-unit.target: **Edit script** - the script file for the table is opened in the Visual Studio Team Services editor.

trans-unit.source: **Manage schema** - add or delete columns or change the table index.
trans-unit.target: **Manage schema** - add or delete columns or change the table index.

trans-unit.source: **Clear table** - truncates an existing table be deleting all data rows but leaving the schema unchanged.
trans-unit.target: **Clear table** - truncates an existing table be deleting all data rows but leaving the schema unchanged.

trans-unit.source: **Delete rows** - delete individual rows of data.
trans-unit.target: **Delete rows** - delete individual rows of data.

trans-unit.source: **View streaming logs** - connects you to the streaming log service for your site.
trans-unit.target: **View streaming logs** - connects you to the streaming log service for your site.

trans-unit.source: How to: Work with Easy APIs in the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: How to: Work with Easy APIs in the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: When you click **Easy APIs** in your backend site settings, you can add a new custom API endpoint or modify or delete an existing API endpoint.
trans-unit.target: When you click **Easy APIs** in your backend site settings, you can add a new custom API endpoint or modify or delete an existing API endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Work with Easy APIs
trans-unit.target: Work with Easy APIs

trans-unit.source: In the portal, you can change the access permissions for a given HTTP action, edit the API script file in the Visual Studio Team Services editor, or view the streaming logs.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, you can change the access permissions for a given HTTP action, edit the API script file in the Visual Studio Team Services editor, or view the streaming logs.

trans-unit.source: How to: Edit code in Visual Studio Team Services
trans-unit.target: How to: Edit code in Visual Studio Team Services

trans-unit.source: The Azure portal lets you edit your Node.js backend script files in Visual Studio Team Services without having to download the project to your local computer.
trans-unit.target: The Azure portal lets you edit your Node.js backend script files in Visual Studio Team Services without having to download the project to your local computer.

trans-unit.source: To edit script files in the online editor:
trans-unit.target: To edit script files in the online editor:

trans-unit.source: In your Mobile App backend blade, click **All settings** > either **Easy tables** or **Easy APIs**, click a table or API, then click **Edit script**.
trans-unit.target: In your Mobile App backend blade, click **All settings** > either **Easy tables** or **Easy APIs**, click a table or API, then click **Edit script**.

trans-unit.source: The script file is opened in the Visual Studio Team Services editor.
trans-unit.target: The script file is opened in the Visual Studio Team Services editor.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio Team Services code editor
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio Team Services code editor

trans-unit.source: Make your changes to the code file in the online editor.
trans-unit.target: Make your changes to the code file in the online editor.

trans-unit.source: Changes are saved automatically as you type.
trans-unit.target: Changes are saved automatically as you type.

trans-unit.source: From the editor, you can also execute the code on the site
trans-unit.target: From the editor, you can also execute the code on the site
